title: Isaiah 41:10 Quiz
description: Test your knowledge of Isaiah 41:10 — God's promise to strengthen, help, and uphold His people — and its surrounding context in Isaiah 41.

questions.question: What is the first command God gives in Isaiah 41:10?
questions.explanation: Isaiah 41:10 begins with 'Fear thou not; for I am with thee.' God's first command is a direct prohibition against fear, grounded in the promise of His presence.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 41:10, what reason does God give for the command 'Fear thou not'?
options: For I have called thee by name
questions.explanation: God's reason for removing fear is His presence: 'Fear thou not; for I am with thee.' The antidote to fear is not the absence of danger but the presence of God.

questions.question: In Isaiah 41:10, what does God tell His people NOT to be, in addition to not fearing?
questions.explanation: The verse reads: 'Be not dismayed; for I am thy God.' To be dismayed means to look around anxiously in terror. God counters this by declaring Himself as their God — the covenant-keeping LORD.

questions.question: How many specific promises does God make about what He will do in Isaiah 41:10?
options: Four: protect, strengthen, help, and uphold
One: uphold with His right hand
questions.explanation: God makes three distinct promises in Isaiah 41:10: 'I will strengthen thee; yea, I will help thee; yea, I will uphold thee with the right hand of my righteousness.' Each promise builds upon the last.

questions.question: With what does God promise to uphold His people in Isaiah 41:10?
options: The right hand of my righteousness
questions.correctAnswer: The right hand of my righteousness
questions.explanation: Isaiah 41:10 concludes: 'I will uphold thee with the right hand of my righteousness.' The right hand symbolizes power and authority; God's own righteousness is the basis for His support of His people.

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 41:10 was originally spoken by God to comfort Israel during the threat of Babylonian exile.
questions.explanation: Isaiah chapters 40-66 are often called the 'Book of Comfort,' written to encourage Israel as they faced the Babylonian captivity. God assured them that despite exile, He would remain with them and restore them.

questions.question: Who wrote the book of Isaiah?
options: The prophet Isaiah, son of Amoz
questions.correctAnswer: The prophet Isaiah, son of Amoz
questions.explanation: Isaiah 1:1 identifies the author: 'The vision of Isaiah the son of Amoz.' Isaiah prophesied during the reigns of Uzziah, Jotham, Ahaz, and Hezekiah, kings of Judah — approximately 740-680 BC.

questions.question: In Isaiah 41:13, God expands on His promise from 41:10. What does He say He will do?
options: Hold thy right hand and say, Fear not; I will help thee
Send an angel to go before thee
questions.correctAnswer: Hold thy right hand and say, Fear not; I will help thee
questions.explanation: Isaiah 41:13 reads: 'For I the LORD thy God will hold thy right hand, saying unto thee, Fear not; I will help thee.' This intensifies the promise — God personally takes His people by the hand.

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 40:31 promises that 'they that wait upon the LORD shall renew their strength; they shall mount up with wings as eagles.'
questions.explanation: Isaiah 40:31 is a closely related promise of divine strength: 'But they that wait upon the LORD shall renew their strength; they shall mount up with wings as eagles; they shall run, and not be weary; and they shall walk, and not faint.'

questions.question: Which of these is NOT one of the 'fear not' passages in the book of Isaiah?
options: Isaiah 41:10 — 'Fear thou not; for I am with thee'
Isaiah 43:1 — 'Fear not: for I have redeemed thee'
Isaiah 44:2 — 'Fear not, O Jacob, my servant'
questions.explanation: Isaiah 55:1 is an invitation to come to the waters, not a 'fear not' passage. Isaiah has a powerful pattern of 'fear not' declarations: 41:10, 41:13, 43:1, 43:5, and 44:2, each grounding courage in God's character and covenant.

questions.question: In Isaiah 41:1-4, God challenges the nations to present their case. Who does He say raised up a 'righteous man from the east'?
questions.explanation: In Isaiah 41:2-4, God declares that He Himself raised up a righteous conqueror from the east (often understood as Cyrus of Persia), demonstrating His sovereignty over all nations and history.

questions.question: Complete this verse from Isaiah 43:1: 'Fear not: for I have ___ thee, I have called thee by thy name; thou art mine.'
questions.explanation: Isaiah 43:1 reads: 'Fear not: for I have redeemed thee, I have called thee by thy name; thou art mine.' This is one of Isaiah's most powerful 'fear not' passages, linking God's removal of fear to His act of redemption.

questions.question: What does the phrase 'be not dismayed' mean in Isaiah 41:10?
options: Do not look around anxiously in terror or dread
Do not be sad or sorrowful
Do not be angry at your enemies
Do not be confused about doctrine
questions.correctAnswer: Do not look around anxiously in terror or dread
questions.explanation: The Hebrew word translated 'dismayed' (sha'ah) means to gaze anxiously about in terror, looking everywhere for help. God's answer is to stop looking around in fear and look to Him: 'for I am thy God.'

questions.question: True or False: In the Old Testament, the 'right hand' of God symbolizes weakness and submission.
questions.explanation: In Scripture, the right hand of God consistently symbolizes power, authority, honor, and salvation — never weakness. Psalm 118:16 says, 'The right hand of the LORD is exalted: the right hand of the LORD doeth valiantly.' Isaiah 41:10 uses this image to promise God's sovereign support.

questions.question: Complete this phrase from Isaiah 41:10: 'I will strengthen thee; yea, I will ___ thee.'
questions.explanation: The full verse reads: 'I will strengthen thee; yea, I will help thee; yea, I will uphold thee with the right hand of my righteousness.' God promises to help — He is not a distant God but an active helper of His people.
